name: pipe
description: A powerful text-processing tool for pattern scanning and data extraction.
long_description: The pipe (|) in Linux is a powerful tool for chaining commands together. It takes the output of one command and uses it as the input for another. This allows for complex data processing and manipulation directly in the terminal. Pipes are commonly used for tasks like filtering, sorting, and transforming data.
details: Pipes are used to connect the output of one command to the input of another.
They are essential for creating command chains that process data sequentially.
Pipes can be combined with other shell features like redirection and background processing.
Common use cases include filtering lists, processing text files, and aggregating data.

name: alias
description: Create or list command aliases.
long_description: The alias command allows users to create custom shortcuts for commands. This is particularly useful for simplifying complex or frequently used commands. Aliases can be defined in the shell configuration file (e.g., .bashrc or .zshrc) to persist across sessions. Users can also list all defined aliases or remove specific ones using the unalias command.
details: Aliases are user-defined shortcuts for commands.
They can include options and arguments to streamline repetitive tasks.
Aliases are session-specific unless added to a shell configuration file.
Use the unalias command to remove an alias.

options.--all: List all aliases, including those defined by the system.

name: apropos
description: Search for commands related to a keyword.
long_description: The apropos command searches the manual page descriptions for a given keyword and lists relevant commands. It is useful when you do not know the exact command name but know its function.
details: keyword: A word related to the command you are searching for.

options.-a: Match all keywords instead of any.
options.-s [section]: Search within a specific manual section.

name: arch
description: Display the machine architecture.
long_description: The arch command prints the computer's architecture type (e.g., x86_64, i686, arm). It is useful for determining compatibility when installing software or compiling programs.
details: No arguments are required.
Outputs the system architecture.

name: ar
description: Create, modify, and extract from archives.
long_description: The ar command is used to create, update, extract, and manipulate archive files, typically used for static libraries in Linux. These archives usually contain compiled object files.
details: archive-file: The archive to create or modify.
file(s): The files to be added to or extracted from the archive.

options.t: List the contents of the archive.

name: at
description: Schedule a command to run at a later time.
long_description: The at command schedules commands for execution at a specific time in the future. It runs the specified command once at the given time.
details: TIME: The time at which the command should run (e.g., 12:30, midnight, noon, now + 1 hour).

options.-f: Read commands from a file instead of standard input.

name: awk
description: A powerful pattern scanning and processing language.
long_description: The awk command in Linux is a versatile programming language designed for pattern scanning and processing. It is commonly used for extracting and manipulating data from text files or streams. awk processes input line by line, splitting each line into fields based on a delimiter (default is whitespace), and allows users to perform actions based on patterns or conditions.
details: PATTERN: A condition or pattern to match lines in the input.
ACTION: Commands to execute when the pattern matches.
FILE: The file(s) to process. If no file is specified, awk reads from standard input.

options.-F: Specify the field separator (e.g., -F: for colon-separated fields).
options.-v: Assign a value to a variable (e.g., -v var=value).
options.-f: Read the awk script from a file.

name: basename
description: Extract the filename from a path.
long_description: The basename command removes the directory path from a file path and returns only the filename. It is useful in scripts when processing file paths.
details: path: The full file path.
suffix: An optional suffix to remove from the filename.

options.-s: Remove a specified suffix from the filename.

name: bc
description: A command-line calculator with arbitrary precision.
long_description: The bc command is an interactive calculator that supports floating-point arithmetic, variables, and functions. It can be used directly from the command line or within scripts for mathematical operations.
details: Reads input from standard input or files.
Supports advanced mathematical calculations.

name: bg
description: Resume a suspended job in the background.
long_description: The bg command resumes a paused (suspended) job and runs it in the background. It is used when managing multiple processes in a shell session.
details: job_spec: The job ID or job number to resume.

name: bzip2
description: Compress files using the Burrows-Wheeler block sorting algorithm.
long_description: The bzip2 command compresses files using a more efficient algorithm than gzip. It produces .bz2 files, which are smaller in size compared to gzip compression.
details: file: The file to compress.

options.-k: Keep the original file after compression.

name: cal
description: Display a calendar in the terminal.
long_description: The cal command prints a simple calendar for the current month by default. It can display a specific month, year, or an entire year.
details: month: The month (1-12) to display.
year: The year to display.

name: cat
description: Concatenate and display file contents.
long_description: The cat command reads files sequentially and outputs their content to the standard output. It is commonly used for viewing, merging, and creating files.
details: file: One or more files to display.

options.-E: Display $ at the end of each line.

name: cd
description: Change the current working directory.
long_description: The cd command is used to navigate between directories in a Linux system. It allows users to move to different locations within the filesystem.
details: directory: The path to the directory to move to.

name: chgrp
description: Change the group ownership of a file or directory.
long_description: The chgrp command changes the group associated with a file or directory. It is useful for managing file permissions in a multi-user environment.
details: group: The new group name or ID.
file: The file or directory to modify.

name: chmod
description: Change file permissions.
long_description: The chmod command modifies file and directory permissions. It allows users to grant or restrict read, write, and execute permissions.
details: mode: The new permission settings (e.g., 755, u+r, g-w).
file: The file or directory to modify.

name: chown
description: Change file owner and group.
long_description: The chown command changes the ownership of files and directories. It allows administrators to assign new owners and groups to files.
details: owner: The new owner's username or UID.
group: The new group (optional).
file: The file or directory to modify.

name: chroot
description: Run a command or shell in a modified root directory.
long_description: The chroot command changes the root directory for a process and its children. This is often used for creating isolated environments, such as system recovery or testing.
details: new-root: The new root directory.
command: The command to execute within the new root.

name: clear
description: Clear the terminal screen.
long_description: The clear command erases all output from the terminal screen, providing a clean workspace. It does not delete command history.
details: No arguments are required.

name: cmp
description: Compare two files byte by byte.
long_description: The cmp command checks if two files are identical. If there is a difference, it outputs the byte and line number where they first differ.
details: file1: The first file to compare.
file2: The second file to compare.

options.-l: Display differences in a detailed format.
options.-s: Suppress all output; only return an exit status.

name: comm
description: Compare two sorted files line by line.
long_description: The comm command takes two sorted files and outputs three columns: lines unique to file1, lines unique to file2, and common lines.
details: file1: The first sorted file.
file2: The second sorted file.

options.-3: Suppress lines common to both files.

name: cp
description: Copy files and directories.
long_description: The cp command is used to copy files or directories from one location to another. It can preserve attributes and copy directories recursively.
details: source: The file or directory to copy.
destination: The location where the file should be copied.

options.-i: Prompt before overwriting an existing file.

name: cron
description: Daemon to execute scheduled commands.
long_description: The cron command schedules and automates tasks to run at specific times or intervals. Users define jobs in a crontab file.
details: Runs in the background and executes scheduled tasks.

name: crontab
description: Manage scheduled tasks in cron.
long_description: The crontab command is used to edit, list, or remove scheduled tasks in the cron job scheduler. Each user has their own crontab file.
details: Schedules commands to run at specified times.

name: curl
description: Transfer data from or to a server.
long_description: The curl command is used to transfer data using various protocols like HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, and more. It is commonly used for downloading files and making API requests.
details: URL: The address of the file or API to fetch data from.

options.-O: Download file and save it with its original name.
options.-o [filename]: Save output to a specific file.

name: cut
description: Remove sections from each line of input.
long_description: The cut command extracts sections of a file or input based on a delimiter, character position, or field.
details: file: The file or input to process.

name: date
description: Display or set the system date and time.
long_description: The date command prints the current system date and time. It can also be used to format dates or set the system clock.
details: Displays or sets the date and time.

name: df
description: Report file system disk space usage.
long_description: The df command displays information about disk space usage for file systems, including total size, used space, and available space.
details: Shows disk space usage for mounted file systems.

name: diff
description: Compare the differences between two files.
long_description: The diff command compares two files line by line and shows the differences between them. It is useful for tracking changes in text files.
details: file1: The first file to compare.
file2: The second file to compare.

options.-q: Suppress output; only show if files differ.

name: dig
description: Query DNS records for a domain.
long_description: The dig command retrieves DNS records for a domain, providing detailed information about name servers, IP addresses, and mail exchanges.
details: domain: The domain name to query.

name: du
description: Estimate file space usage.
long_description: The du command calculates and displays the disk usage of files and directories. It is useful for finding large files and monitoring storage usage.
details: directory: The directory to analyze (default is the current directory).

options.-s: Show only the total size for each directory.

name: echo
description: Display a message or the value of a variable.
long_description: The echo command prints text to the terminal. It is commonly used in scripts to display messages, variable values, or formatted output.
details: string: The text to display.

options.-n: Do not print a newline at the end.

name: env
description: Display or modify environment variables.
long_description: The env command prints the environment variables or runs a command with modified environment settings.
details: command: The command to execute with modified environment variables.

options.VAR=value: Set an environment variable for the command.

name: exit
description: Exit the current shell session.
long_description: The exit command terminates the shell session or a script. An optional exit code can be specified to indicate success or failure.
details: exit_code: A numeric value indicating success (0) or failure (non-zero).

name: export
description: Set an environment variable for child processes.
long_description: The export command defines environment variables that persist for child processes of the current shell.
details: VAR: The name of the variable.
value: The value assigned to the variable.

name: find
description: Search for files and directories.
long_description: The find command locates files and directories based on name, type, size, modification time, and other criteria.
details: directory: The starting location for the search.

options.-name [pattern]: Search for files matching a name pattern.

name: free
description: Display memory usage information.
long_description: The free command shows the total, used, and available memory (RAM and swap) in the system.
details: Displays information about system memory usage.

name: grep
description: Search for a pattern in a file or input.
long_description: The grep command searches for a specified pattern in files or standard input. It is useful for filtering text and extracting relevant lines.
details: pattern: The text pattern to search for.
file: The file(s) to search in.

options.-v: Invert match (show lines that do not match).

name: groupadd
description: Create a new user group.
long_description: The groupadd command is used to create new user groups in the system.
details: group_name: The name of the new group.

name: head
description: Display the first few lines of a file.
long_description: The head command prints the first 10 lines of a file by default. It is useful for quickly viewing the beginning of large files.
details: file: The file(s) to read from.

options.-n [number]: Specify the number of lines to display.

name: hostname
description: Display or set the system's hostname.
long_description: The hostname command shows the system's network name. It can also be used to set a new hostname.
details: Displays or changes the hostname.

options.-f: Show the fully qualified domain name (FQDN).

name: id
description: Display user ID (UID) and group ID (GID) information.
long_description: The id command prints user and group IDs for the current or specified user. It helps in checking permissions and user privileges.
details: username: The user to check (optional, defaults to the current user).

options.-G: Show all group IDs associated with the user.

name: ifconfig
description: Configure or display network interface settings.
long_description: The ifconfig command is used to display or modify network interface settings, such as IP addresses, netmasks, and MAC addresses.
details: interface: The network interface to configure (e.g., eth0, wlan0).

name: iptables
description: Manage firewall rules on Linux.
long_description: The iptables command configures the Linux kernel firewall, allowing administrators to define rules for packet filtering and network security.
details: Used to define rules for incoming and outgoing traffic.

options.-A: Append a rule to a chain.
options.-D: Delete a rule from a chain.

name: kill
description: Send a signal to a process, usually to terminate it.
long_description: The kill command sends signals to processes by specifying their process ID (PID). It is often used to stop unresponsive programs.
details: PID: The process ID of the target program.

name: less
description: View file contents page by page.
long_description: The less command allows users to view large files page by page, with options for navigation and search.
details: file: The file to read.

options.-s: Squeeze multiple blank lines into one.

name: ln
description: Create links between files.
long_description: The ln command creates hard or symbolic (soft) links between files, allowing multiple references to the same file.
details: target: The original file.
link_name: The new link name.

name: ls
description: List files and directories.
long_description: The ls command displays the contents of a directory, including files and subdirectories. It supports various options for sorting and displaying information.
details: directory: The directory to list (defaults to the current directory).

options.-h: Show file sizes in human-readable format.

name: man
description: Display the manual page for a command.
long_description: The man command retrieves and displays the manual pages for Linux commands, providing detailed usage information and options.
details: command: The command to look up in the manual.

options.-k: Search for a command by keyword.

name: mkdir
description: Create a new directory.
long_description: The mkdir command allows users to create new directories in a specified location.
details: directory_name: The name of the new directory.

options.-p: Create parent directories if they don't exist.
options.-m: Set permissions for the new directory.

name: mv
description: Move or rename files and directories.
long_description: The mv command moves files or directories from one location to another. It is also used to rename files.
details: source: The file or directory to move.
destination: The new location or name.

name: rmdir
description: Remove empty directories.
long_description: The rmdir command deletes empty directories. Unlike 'rm -r', it does not remove directories containing files.
details: directory: The empty directory to remove.

options.--ignore-fail-on-non-empty: Suppress errors if the directory is not empty.

name: scp
description: Securely copy files between hosts over SSH.
long_description: The scp command securely transfers files between local and remote hosts using SSH encryption.
details: source: The file to copy (local or remote).
destination: The target location (local or remote).

name: sed
description: Stream editor for modifying text in files.
long_description: The sed command processes and transforms text in files using pattern-based replacements.
details: pattern: The text pattern to search for.
replacement: The text to replace the pattern with.
file: The file to modify.

name: shutdown
description: Power off or reboot the system.
long_description: The shutdown command schedules or immediately powers off or reboots a Linux system.
details: time: Specifies when to shut down (e.g., 'now', '+10' for 10 minutes later).
message: An optional broadcast message for users.

name: sort
description: Sort lines of text files.
long_description: The sort command arranges lines of text in a specified order, such as alphabetical or numerical sorting.
details: file: The file containing the lines to sort.

name: ssh
description: Securely connect to remote machines over SSH.
long_description: The ssh command allows users to securely log into remote servers and execute commands over an encrypted connection.
details: user: The remote username.
host: The remote machine's hostname or IP address.

options.-i: Specify a private key for authentication.

name: stat
description: Display detailed information about files and directories.
long_description: The stat command shows detailed attributes of a file, such as size, modification time, and permissions.
details: file: The file or directory to inspect.

name: su
description: Switch to another user account.
long_description: The su command allows a user to switch to another user’s account, typically root, to execute commands with elevated privileges.
details: username: The user account to switch to (default is root).

options.-c: Execute a command as the specified user.

name: tail
description: Display the last lines of a file.
long_description: The tail command outputs the last few lines of a file, commonly used for monitoring log files.
details: file: The file to read.

options.-n: Specify the number of lines to display.
options.-f: Follow the file for real-time updates.

name: tar
description: Archive files using the tar format.
long_description: The tar command creates, extracts, or modifies tar archive files, commonly used for backups and file transfers.
details: archive: The name of the tar file.
file(s): The files or directories to include.

name: tee
description: Read from standard input and write to both standard output and a file.
long_description: The tee command takes input, displays it on the terminal, and simultaneously writes it to a file.
details: file: The file to write the output to.

options.-a: Append to the file instead of overwriting.

name: top
description: Display real-time system resource usage and running processes.
long_description: The top command provides a live view of system performance, including CPU and memory usage by processes.
details: Displays system statistics and active processes.

name: touch
description: Create empty files or update file timestamps.
long_description: The touch command is used to create empty files or modify the last access and modification timestamps of existing files.
details: file: The file to create or update.

options.-c: Do not create the file if it does not exist.

name: tr
description: Translate or delete characters in text.
long_description: The tr command replaces or removes characters from input, useful for text processing tasks.
details: set1: The characters to translate or delete.
set2: The replacement characters (if translating).

options.-s: Replace repeated characters with a single instance.

name: uname
description: Display system information.
long_description: The uname command prints system-related details like kernel name, version, and architecture.
details: Displays information about the system.

name: uptime
description: Show how long the system has been running.
long_description: The uptime command provides the current time, system uptime duration, and the number of logged-in users.
details: Displays system uptime and user statistics.

name: useradd
description: Create a new user account.
long_description: The useradd command adds a new user to the system, creating a home directory and setting initial account settings.
details: username: The name of the user to add.

options.-m: Create a home directory for the user.
options.-G [group]: Add the user to a specific group.

name: usermod
description: Modify an existing user account.
long_description: The usermod command updates user account settings such as username, group membership, or shell.
details: username: The name of the user to modify.

options.-aG [group]: Add the user to an additional group.

name: vi
description: A powerful text editor.
long_description: The vi command launches the Vi text editor, an advanced terminal-based text editor with powerful editing features.
details: file: The file to edit or create if it does not exist.

options.-R: Open the file in read-only mode.

name: wc
description: Count lines, words, and characters in a file.
long_description: The wc command counts the number of lines, words, and characters in a given file or input.
details: file: The file to analyze.

name: wget
description: Download files from the web.
long_description: The wget command is a non-interactive utility for downloading files from the internet, supporting HTTP, HTTPS, and FTP protocols.
details: URL: The web address of the file to download.

options.-O [file]: Save the downloaded file with a custom name.

name: which
description: Locate the executable file of a command.
long_description: The which command finds the full path of the executable associated with a given command name.
details: command: The name of the command to locate.

options.-a: Show all locations of the command in the PATH.

name: who
description: Show logged-in users.
long_description: The who command displays information about users currently logged into the system.
details: Displays a list of active user sessions.

options.-b: Show the last system boot time.
options.-m: Show information about the current user only.

name: xargs
description: Build and execute commands from standard input.
long_description: The xargs command takes input from a pipe or file and constructs and executes commands using that input.
details: command: The command to execute using the input.

options.-n [num]: Specify the number of arguments per command.
options.-I [replace]: Define a replacement string for the input.

name: yes
description: Output a string repeatedly until stopped.
long_description: The yes command continuously prints a specified string or 'y' until interrupted.
details: string: The text to output repeatedly (default is 'y').

name: zip
description: Compress files into a ZIP archive.
long_description: The zip command packages multiple files into a compressed ZIP archive.
details: archive: The name of the output ZIP file.
file(s): The files to compress.

options.-r: Recursively add directories to the ZIP archive.
options.-e: Encrypt the ZIP file with a password.

name: zcat
description: View the contents of compressed files without extracting.
long_description: The zcat command displays the content of compressed files without decompressing them first.
details: file.gz: The compressed file to read.

options.-f: Force decompression even if the file does not have a .gz extension.

name: zgrep
description: Search compressed files for a pattern.
long_description: The zgrep command searches inside compressed files for specific patterns, similar to grep.
details: pattern: The text to search for.
file.gz: The compressed file to scan.

options.-c: Display the count of matching lines.

name: zpool
description: Manage ZFS storage pools.
long_description: The zpool command is used to create, destroy, and manage ZFS storage pools.
details: command: A subcommand like create, destroy, status, etc.

options.status: Show the status of all pools.

name: zsh
description: Z Shell, an advanced command-line interpreter.
long_description: The zsh command launches the Z Shell, an alternative to Bash with powerful features such as improved autocomplete and customization.
details: Starts an interactive Zsh session.
